title: Does being cold make you sick?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of colds and the flu?

options.label: A
options.text: Because cold temperatures directly cause illness

options.label: B
options.text: Because people stay indoors more often and are exposed to more pathogens

options.label: C
options.text: Because the days are shorter during the winter

options.label: D
options.text: Because people don't wear jackets outside

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the spread of viruses

options.label: C
options.text: It allows viruses to spread more readily

options.label: D
options.text: It only affects the spread of the flu, not colds

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: It only affects the immune system during the summer

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the study that put test subjects' feet into ice water?

options.label: B
options.text: The subjects were more likely to develop common cold symptoms

options.label: C
options.text: The subjects showed no difference in developing common cold symptoms

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That cold temperatures have no effect on the immune system

options.label: C
options.text: That cold temperatures cause blood vessel constriction, inhibiting the immune response

options.label: D
options.text: That cold temperatures only affect the immune system in people with low Vitamin D levels

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of temperature on the outer layer of the common cold virus?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes harder and more shield-like at cold temperatures

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same at all temperatures

options.label: D
options.text: It only changes at extremely high or low temperatures

multiple-choice.question: How does the immune reaction to the common cold virus change with temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more effective at cold temperatures

options.label: B
options.text: It is less effective at cold temperatures

options.label: C
options.text: It is not affected by temperature

options.label: D
options.text: It is only affected by temperature in people with low Vitamin D levels

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of warm infected cells undergoing programmed cell death?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the virus to spread more easily

options.label: B
options.text: It limits the spread of infection

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the spread of infection

options.label: D
options.text: It only occurs in people with low Vitamin D levels

multiple-choice.question: What is a suggested way to reduce the risk of catching a cold or flu during the winter?

options.label: A
options.text: Staying indoors as much as possible

options.label: B
options.text: Going outside more often, bundled up

options.label: C
options.text: Taking high doses of Vitamin D

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding contact with people who are sick

title: How does herd immunity work?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of vaccines, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect individuals from getting sick

options.label: B
options.text: To protect a whole population from getting sick

What is the term "R0" used to describe in the context of infectious diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of people infected by a single person

options.label: B
options.text: The number of people immune to a disease

options.label: C
options.text: The number of people vaccinated against a disease

options.label: D
options.text: The number of people susceptible to a disease

According to the transcript, what is the effectiveness of the measles vaccine?

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the benefit of combining vaccines with behaviors like mask-wearing and social distancing?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on the effectiveness of vaccines

options.label: D
options.text: It only benefits individuals, not the population

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The benefits and risks of short selling in the stock market

options.label: D
options.text: The role of banks in the 2008 financial crisis

options.label: B
options.text: The investor sells the security in a short position and buys it in a long position

options.label: C

title: Why the ancient Greeks couldn't see blue

multiple-choice.question: What is peculiar about Homer's description of colors in "The Iliad" and "The Odyssey"?

options.label: A
options.text: He describes the ocean as blue.

options.label: B
options.text: He never mentions the color blue.

options.label: D
options.text: He describes the sky as green.

multiple-choice.question: What did researchers initially suggest as a reason for the ancient Greeks not mentioning the color blue?

options.label: B
options.text: They saw colors differently than we do.

options.label: C
options.text: They didn't have a word for blue.

options.label: D
options.text: They didn't interact with blue objects.

multiple-choice.question: What is the order in which colors enter language in every culture, according to linguists?

options.label: A
options.text: Red, yellow, green, blue, black, white

options.label: B
options.text: Black, white, red, yellow, green, blue

options.label: C
options.text: Blue, green, yellow, red, black, white

options.label: D
options.text: Yellow, green, blue, red, black, white

multiple-choice.question: What is the evolutionary explanation for the order in which colors enter language?

options.label: A
options.text: Colors enter language based on their wavelength.

options.label: B
options.text: Colors enter language based on their association with danger or importance.

options.label: C
options.text: Colors enter language based on their usefulness for distinguishing between night and day.

multiple-choice.question: Why is blue the last color to enter language, according to the evolutionary explanation?

options.label: B
options.text: Blue is a rare color in nature.

options.label: D
options.text: Blue is not a useful color for distinguishing between night and day.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second explanation for the order in which colors enter language?

options.label: A
options.text: Colors enter language based on their association with emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: Colors enter language based on their ease of creation.

options.label: C
options.text: Colors enter language based on their importance in nature.

options.label: D
options.text: Colors enter language based on their wavelength.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how language can influence our perception of colors?

options.label: A
options.text: The Himba people of Namibia can distinguish between different shades of blue more easily than English speakers.

options.label: B
options.text: The Himba people of Namibia take longer to distinguish between different shades of blue than English speakers.

options.label: C
options.text: English speakers can distinguish between different shades of green more easily than the Himba people of Namibia.

options.label: D
options.text: The Himba people of Namibia and English speakers can distinguish between different shades of blue equally well.

multiple-choice.question: What did anthropologists discover about the indigenous islanders of New Guinea's description of the sky?

options.label: A
options.text: They described the sky as blue.

options.label: B
options.text: They described the sky as black or dirty like water.

options.label: C
options.text: They described the sky as green.

options.label: D
options.text: They described the sky as red.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of language on our brain's perception of colors, according to neuroscience?

options.label: A
options.text: Language has no effect on our brain's perception of colors.

options.label: B
options.text: Language trains our brain to see colors more similarly.

options.label: C
options.text: Language trains our brain to see colors differently.

options.label: D
options.text: Language has a random effect on our brain's perception of colors.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how learning a new language can influence our perception of words?

options.label: A
options.text: We become less able to distinguish between different words.

options.label: B
options.text: We become more able to distinguish between different words.

options.label: C
options.text: We become able to distinguish between different words more slowly.

options.label: D
options.text: We become able to distinguish between different words more quickly, but only for a short time.

title: Why do we get goose bumps?

multiple-choice.question: What is the scientific term for the phenomenon commonly known as goosebumps?
What is the primary function of the arrector pili muscle?

options.label: C
options.text: To contract and make hairs stand upright

options.label: D
options.text: To relax and make hairs lie flat

multiple-choice.question: Why do we experience goosebumps when we're cold?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our hair standing on end creates a buffer between our skin and the cold air

options.label: B
options.text: Because our sympathetic nervous system is triggered

options.label: C
options.text: Because we're experiencing an intense emotional response

options.label: D
options.text: Because our arrector pili muscles are relaxing

options.label: A
options.text: Because it creates anticipation in the brain

options.label: C
options.text: Because it triggers a fight or flight response

multiple-choice.question: What brain structures are activated when we experience goosebumps from music?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they recreate the chilling feeling of social loss

options.label: B
options.text: Because they trigger a fight or flight response

options.label: D
options.text: Because they create anticipation in the brain

options.text: It helps them regulate their body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: It makes them look bigger and scarier to predators

options.label: C
options.text: It helps them simulate social interactions

options.label: D
options.text: It triggers a fight or flight response

options.label: A
options.text: Because they help us regulate our body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: Because they make us look bigger and scarier to predators

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were useful for our ancestors before the development of clothing

options.label: D
options.text: Because they trigger a fight or flight response

title: How to process your emotions

multiple-choice.question: What happens to unprocessed emotions within us?

options.label: A
options.text: They are immediately acknowledged and understood

options.label: B
options.text: They manifest themselves as powerful directionless anxiety

options.label: D
options.text: They have no impact on our mental state

multiple-choice.question: What activities might people engage in to avoid meeting their fears head-on?

options.label: A
options.text: Reading, meditation, and spending time in nature

options.label: B
options.text: Internet pornography, tracking the news, or exercising compulsively

options.label: C
options.text: Talking to friends, writing in a journal, and practicing yoga

options.label: D
options.text: Learning a new skill, volunteering, and playing a musical instrument

multiple-choice.question: How might someone react to hurt or abuse if they are driven to flee from recognition of their vulnerability?

options.label: A
options.text: They will confront the person who hurt them and express their feelings

options.label: B
options.text: They will become withdrawn and isolated

options.label: C
options.text: They will mask their true feelings with a brittle good cheer or cynicism

options.label: D
options.text: They will immediately seek help from a therapist

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of failing to process our feelings?

options.label: A
options.text: We become more confident and self-assured

options.label: B
options.text: We grow more original and creative in our thinking

options.label: C
options.text: We grow depressed about everything because we cannot be sad about something

options.label: D
options.text: We become more outgoing and sociable

multiple-choice.question: What is the underlying reason for insomnia, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a result of too much caffeine consumption

options.label: B
options.text: It is a result of a lack of physical exercise

options.label: C
options.text: It is the revenge of all the many thoughts we've omitted to process in the day

options.label: D
options.text: It is a result of a poor sleep environment

multiple-choice.question: Why do people avoid processing their emotions?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it requires too much effort

options.label: C
options.text: Because what we feel is so contrary to our self-image and society's ideas of normality

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not necessary for mental health

multiple-choice.question: What kind of atmosphere is conducive to processing emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: One in which difficulties are ignored and suppressed

options.label: B
options.text: One in which difficulties are warmly recognized and charitably accepted

options.label: C
options.text: One in which difficulties are ridiculed and dismissed

options.label: D
options.text: One in which difficulties are avoided and denied

multiple-choice.question: What is necessary for processing emotions, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Good friends, deft therapists, and ritual moments like philosophical meditation

options.label: B
options.text: Self-help books, online courses, and solo activities

options.label: C
options.text: Medication, surgery, and other medical interventions

options.label: D
options.text: Social media, television, and other forms of entertainment

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of processing our emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: A worsening of our general mood

options.label: B
options.text: No change in our general mood

options.label: C
options.text: An alleviation in our general mood

options.label: D
options.text: A complete elimination of all emotions

multiple-choice.question: What must we pay for our self-awareness with, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A period of celebration and joy

options.label: B
options.text: A period of mourning and acknowledgment of sadness

options.label: C
options.text: A period of denial and suppression

options.label: D
options.text: A period of distraction and avoidance
